title: Ticket #7508: Don't tune kernel if inside a container
description:
The kernel tuning script, which condor (master?) runs on startup, fails inside unprivileged containers where condor is only UID 0 inside the container, and not outside. It should not run the script if it doesn't have the privileges to tune anything. There are multiple ways to do this:

1. test if inside a container and don't run the tuning script if so

2. test for the right capability (CAP_SYS_ADMIN?) instead of testing the UID
remarks:
2020-Feb-20 15:22:10 by bbockelm:
Note that, by definition, the initial process in the user namespace has CAP_SYS_ADMIN within the namespace.

By design, you can't query if the condor_master has CAP_SYS_ADMIN outside the namespace.

2020-Feb-25 17:14:43 by bbockelm:
@gthain - Docker traditionally doesn't utilize user namespaces (requires more elaborate deployments such as OKD which FNAL uses). Can you confirm it was for your example?

2020-Feb-25 17:17:41 by bbockelm:
Sorry, forgot to leave the other half of the thought:

- This is a good improvement in many cases (as Docker is, uh, not exactly uncommon). - There are some cases where this is a bad heuristic. For the sake of Linux security, I hope these cases are more common in the future. - We should make the lack of these tunings something that HTCondor can manage cleanly (i.e., either fail with a clear message or ignore the failure).
